Award.AwardTitle: Portraits of Place at Palmer Station
Award.AbstractNarration:
Shaun O'Boyle, a Guggenheim Fellow photographer, will join a cruise on the Laurence M. Gould (LMG), traveling to Palmer Station in Antarctica, and document the visual relationships between science and architecture, architecture and landscape, and scientists and the environment. At Palmer, the artist will photograph building interiors, exteriors and infrastructure, overall station panoramas, and scientists working in the field and on station. Similar photographs will be taken aboard the LMG to document ship life, science taking place onboard, infrastructure, and seascapes. The artist intends the project to complement his previous work at McMurdo Station.

This project will provide a historical archive of the U.S. Antarctic Program's (USAP) infrastructure and architecture at Palmer Station. As a stand-alone project, it is outstanding, but it is also an extension of the artist's work documenting McMurdo station, which increases its historical impact. The proposed work will expand the artist's "Antarctica: Portraits of Place" and create a more complete and valuable record of the USAP facilities in this time period. Outreach includes various venues including museum exhibits, lectures, and a blog, each reaching a different audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photography of Palmer Station was the primary goal of this Antarctic Artists and Writers Project, titled Portraits of Place at Palmer Station, by photographer Shaun O’Boyle. Transportation to and from Palmer was on the NSF Icebreker Laurance M. Gould, which included a stop at Cape Shirreff in the South Shetland Island, and passage through the Gerlache Strait and the Neumayer Channel. This was considered to be part of the project and photography was ongoing throughout the passage. On arrival at Palmer station the artist had 6 days to complete a photographic survey of Palmer Station. 


The emphasis of the project was the interface between science and the station, how the station buildings function as extensions of the science happening at Palmer, and how the architecture accommodates science. Photography subjects included interiors and exteriors of all station buildings, with an emphasis on the larger buildings such as the Bio Building, GWR (garage, warehouse, recreation) building, and the Terra Lab. This included photography of scientists and researchers working in the labs and other spaces of the station, as well as daily workings of the station such as station meetings, and activities such as off loading supplies to the station from the LMG and the turn out of many personnel to assist with the storage of 6 months supply of food. Utilitarian and functional spaces such as the power generator room, carpentry and electrical shops, garage and storage spaces were also photographed. 


The surrounding landscapes and their relationship to the station was an important part of the work done at Palmer, and the station was photographed from as many locations as was practicable considering the conditions of the sea ice at the time of the project. Ice moved into the harbor and froze, making travel by boat impossible during the project. 


Photographs of the station and surrounding landscapes were shared through several channels, including the Smithsonian Magazine Instagram feed, a project blog, and facebook posts. Photo galleries of the project currently reside on two websites, new.oboylephoto.com and shanoboylephoto.com. Plans are in the works for a exhibition of the photographs at the Peary-MacMillan Arctic Museum, located at Bowdoin College, in Maine.
